awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coherent Laser Control for Compact Accelerators
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award will support a study of how to enhance performance of laser-driven particle accelerators by controlling laser properties such as the focal spot quality.  Using techniques that enable the laser light to be manipulated and coherently controlled, high brightness compact accelerators may become achievable on a single tabletop, with immediate applications in medical isotope production and radiography. The research is highly integrated with mentoring, professional development, and outreach, which are employed to train students practical skill sets to prepare them for a range of technical careers. The education plan will utilize culturally relevant frameworks for engaging underrepresented populations, providing hands-on skill set development, and empowering the students themselves to increase visibility of accelerator science as a discipline. 
 
Femtosecond lasers are ideally suited for use as tabletop particle accelerators since their short pulse duration enables relativistic intensities to be generated at high repetition rates. With sufficient intensity, a laser can redistribute electrons within optical cycles, generating enormous acceleration gradients which can drive advanced accelerators. Though early analytical models showed promise of GeV ions and hundreds of GeV electrons, experiments have yet to produce such beams.  This CAREER award will enable experiments shaping the wavefront and modifying the polarization of femtosecond lasers towards development of practical tabletop accelerators.  Influence of higher order modes for increased charge and decreased beam divergence will be studied, with machine learning providing insight into the respective influence of each mode in these highly nonlinear regimes. Numerical modeling of the interactions will be performed utilizing large data samples and exactly measured beam properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When light is intense enough, it behaves very differently than in our everyday lives. New laser technology can make light so intense that it can push matter to nearly the speed of light. By understanding how this intense light interacts with matter, we can harness these interactions to create compact sources of electrons and x-ray beams. These beams occur on some of the fastest timescales—on the order of a femtosecond (a millionth of a billionth of a second)—providing opportunities to observe some of the quickest events known to humankind.
When a boat moves quickly through water, it pushes the water out of its way and creates a wave behind it. A surfer can ride this wave, gaining speed as it travels. Focusing a laser beam into a puff of gas produces a very similar event, with the boat replaced by the laser and the water replaced by plasma—the material that makes up the sun and into which the gas turns when the laser is strong enough. A particle such as an electron replaces the surfer and can gain very high energies over a distance of only an inch or two. When a charged particle like an electron changes speed or direction, it emits light. Under the high intensity of this interaction, that light can be in the form of x-rays.
In this CAREER award, we studied how the processes of accelerating electrons and generating x-rays change when we manipulate the properties of light. These properties include the shape of the focus, the duration of the laser pulse, the color (wavelength) of the laser used, and the direction in which the light wave oscillates (polarization). We found new means of making even shorter laser pulses and demonstrated that they can accelerate electrons just as effectively as longer pulses with less energy. We showed that by changing the polarization of the laser, the conditions required for accelerating electrons became more relaxed while also accelerating more electrons. We examined how the quantum nature of polarization affects the interactions, where different polarizations couple to different quantum properties such as spin angular momentum and orbital angular momentum. The work has already resulted in six publications, with several more in preparation. The experiments were conducted on several laser systems across the nation, with the most recent work taking place during the first awarded experimental time on the ZEUS Laser Facility, the most powerful laser in the U.S.
Additionally, we established new peer mentorship programs in the physical sciences. By providing mentorship training to graduate students and establishing a series of structured conversations that target anxiety points in the graduate student experience, we began to positively impact the overall climate in the department while also providing critical professional development. We also hosted a new undergraduate research program called CARE-NA, which provided cultural context for accelerator science relevant to Native American students. To date, we have had four Native American students participate, with one currently in a graduate physics program.
